title: Migraine with Aura - Acute Episode Management
content:
Patient presented to clinic with severe unilateral headache with visual disturbances, reporting symptoms began approximately 2 hours ago.

Chief Complaint:
"I have a terrible headache on the left side of my head, and I saw flashing lights before it started. The pain is unbearable."

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 32-year-old with history of episodic migraines. Current episode began this morning with visual aura (seeing zigzag lines and flashing lights) lasting approximately 20-30 minutes, followed by severe left-sided throbbing headache. Rates pain as 8/10 in severity. Associated with nausea, photophobia (light sensitivity), and phonophobia (sound sensitivity). Took over-the-counter ibuprofen 400mg without significant relief. No vomiting yet but feels nauseous. Has retreated to dark, quiet room which provides minimal relief.

Migraine History:
- First migraine at age 18
- Average frequency: 3-4 episodes per month
- Typical duration: 4-24 hours if untreated
- Known triggers: stress, lack of sleep, hormonal changes (menstrual cycle), certain foods (aged cheese, red wine), bright lights
- Previous successful treatments: Sumatriptan, rest in dark room

Aura Characteristics:
- Visual aura most common (zigzag lines, flashing lights, blind spots)
- Develops over 5-20 minutes
- Lasts 20-60 minutes
- Always precedes headache
- No motor or sensory symptoms

Current Episode Triggers:
- High stress at work this week
- Only 4 hours sleep last night
- Skipped breakfast this morning
- Menstrual period started yesterday

Associated Symptoms:
- Nausea (no vomiting)
- Photophobia (severe)
- Phonophobia (moderate)
- Mild neck stiffness
- Fatigue

Denies:
- Fever
- Head trauma
- Neck rigidity (meningeal signs)
- New neurological symptoms
- Change in migraine pattern
- Worst headache of life

Current Medications:
- Birth control pills (Ortho Tri-Cyclen)
- Occasional ibuprofen for migraines
- No daily preventive migraine medication

Past Medical History:
- Migraine with aura (since age 18)
- Otherwise healthy
- No cardiovascular disease
- No seizure history

Family History:
- Mother has migraines
- Maternal aunt has migraines
- Strong family history of migraine disorder

Social History:
- Works as accountant (high stress)
- Non-smoker
- Occasional alcohol (red wine sometimes triggers migraines)
- Regular exercise when not having headache
- Caffeine: 2-3 cups coffee daily

Vital Signs:
- Blood Pressure: 128/82 mmHg (slightly elevated, likely due to pain)
- Heart Rate: 88 bpm, regular
- Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths/min
- Temperature: 98.4Â°F (afebrile)
- Oxygen Saturation: 99% on room air

Physical Examination:
- General: Appears uncomfortable, lying quietly with eyes closed, dim lighting preferred
- HEENT: 
  * Normocephalic, no scalp tenderness
  * Pupils equal, round, reactive to light (mildly photophobic)
  * Extraocular movements intact
  * No papilledema on fundoscopic exam
  * Temporal arteries non-tender, no thickening
- Neck: Supple, no meningeal signs, mild paraspinal muscle tenderness
- Neurological Examination:
  * Alert and oriented x3
  * Cranial nerves II-XII intact
  * Motor: Strength 5/5 in all extremities
  * Sensory: Intact to light touch and pinprick
  * Reflexes: 2+ and symmetric
  * Coordination: Finger-to-nose intact
  * Gait: Not assessed (deferred due to severe headache)
  * No focal neurological deficits
- Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
- Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally

Neurological Red Flags Assessment:
- No fever (rules out meningitis/encephalitis)
- No sudden onset worst headache (rules out SAH)
- No focal neurological deficits (rules out stroke)
- No papilledema (rules out increased ICP)
- Aura pattern consistent with previous episodes
- No new or different features

Diagnostic Studies:
- None required for typical migraine with known history
- Neuroimaging not indicated (no red flags present)
- Previous MRI brain (2 years ago): Normal
diagnosis:
Migraine with Aura - Acute Episode

Primary Diagnosis:
Migraine with typical aura, currently in acute headache phase. Diagnosis based on:
- History of recurrent similar episodes
- Classic visual aura preceding headache
- Unilateral throbbing headache
- Associated symptoms (nausea, photophobia, phonophobia)
- Normal neurological examination
- Identifiable triggers (stress, sleep deprivation, hormonal, missed meal)

Classification:
- Migraine with aura (ICHD-3 criteria met)
- Episodic migraine (3-4 episodes per month)
- Moderate to severe intensity during attacks
- Significant disability during episodes

Migraine Pattern:
- Consistent with patient's usual migraine presentation
- No concerning new features
- Predictable triggers identified
- Responsive to previous triptan therapy

No Red Flags Present:
- No signs of secondary headache
- No neurological deficits
- No features suggesting structural pathology
- Headache pattern unchanged from baseline

Frequency Assessment:
With 3-4 episodes per month, patient meets criteria for consideration of preventive therapy. Current episodic pattern causing significant impact on quality of life and work productivity.

Contributing Factors:
- Hormonal fluctuations (menstrual-related)
- Sleep deprivation
- High stress levels
- Irregular meal timing
- Possible medication overuse (to be monitored)
prescription:
Acute Migraine Treatment:

1. Sumatriptan 100mg tablets
   - Take 1 tablet at onset of headache (can take during aura phase)
   - If headache returns or only partially relieved, may take second dose after 2 hours
   - Maximum: 200mg per 24 hours
   - Quantity: 9 tablets (for 3 acute episodes)
   - Do not use if chest pain or cardiovascular risk factors develop
   - May cause tingling, flushing, or tightness in chest/neck (usually harmless)

2. Metoclopramide 10mg tablets (anti-nausea)
   - Take 1 tablet with sumatriptan for nausea
   - Can take up to 3 times daily if needed
   - Take 30 minutes before eating if nausea prevents eating
   - Quantity: 9 tablets

3. Ondansetron 4mg ODT (dissolving tablet) - Alternative anti-nausea
   - Place one tablet under tongue at onset of nausea
   - May repeat every 8 hours if needed
   - Useful if vomiting prevents oral medications
   - Quantity: 6 tablets

Rescue Medication (if triptans contraindicated or ineffective):

4. Naproxen Sodium 500mg
   - Take 1-2 tablets at headache onset
   - May repeat once after 12 hours
   - Take with food
   - Quantity: 20 tablets

Preventive Therapy - Starting Today:

5. Propranolol 40mg extended-release
   - Take 1 capsule daily in the morning
   - Start at 40mg; may increase to 80mg after 2 weeks if tolerated
   - Do not stop abruptly
   - Monitor blood pressure and heart rate
   - May cause fatigue initially (usually improves)
   - Quantity: 60 capsules (2 months supply)
   - Goal: Reduce frequency and severity of migraines

6. Magnesium Oxide 400mg (Over-the-counter supplement)
   - Take 1 tablet daily for migraine prevention
   - May help reduce migraine frequency
   - Can cause loose stools (reduce dose if occurs)

Supplemental Recommendations:
- Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) 400mg daily - OTC migraine prevention
- Coenzyme Q10 100mg three times daily - OTC migraine prevention

Medication Use Guidelines:
- Limit acute migraine medication to <10 days per month to avoid medication overuse headache
- Keep headache diary to track medication use
- Take acute medication early in attack for best results
- Do not drive or operate machinery while having migraine
recommendations:
Immediate Management (Next 24-48 hours):

1. Rest and Environment:
   - Rest in dark, quiet room
   - Apply cold compress to forehead and neck
   - Avoid bright lights and loud noises
   - Minimize screen time (phone, computer, TV)
   - Sleep if possible (sleep often resolves migraine)

2. Hydration and Nutrition:
   - Drink plenty of water (dehydration worsens migraine)
   - Small, bland meals if able to eat
   - Avoid known trigger foods
   - Caffeine may help (one cup of coffee) if not already consumed

3. When to Use Medications:
   - Take sumatriptan as soon as headache begins
   - Do not wait for severe pain
   - Earlier treatment = better results
   - Take anti-nausea medication if needed

Long-term Migraine Management:

1. Trigger Identification and Avoidance:
   - Keep detailed headache diary (frequency, severity, triggers, treatments)
   - Document: food, sleep, stress, weather, menstrual cycle
   - Identify patterns over 2-3 months
   - Common triggers to monitor:
     * Foods: aged cheese, processed meats, MSG, artificial sweeteners
     * Drinks: alcohol (especially red wine), excessive caffeine
     * Sleep: too little or too much
     * Stress and emotions
     * Hormonal changes
     * Weather changes
     * Sensory stimuli: bright lights, loud sounds, strong odors

2. Lifestyle Modifications:
   - Regular sleep schedule (7-9 hours, same bedtime/wake time)
   - Regular meal times (don't skip meals)
   - Stay well-hydrated (8-10 glasses water daily)
   - Regular exercise (30 min, 5 days/week) - avoid during active migraine
   - Stress management techniques
   - Limit caffeine to 1-2 servings per day (consistent amount)

3. Stress Management:
   - Progressive muscle relaxation
   - Deep breathing exercises
   - Meditation or mindfulness practice
   - Yoga or gentle stretching
   - Cognitive behavioral therapy (consider referral)
   - Biofeedback training
   - Adequate work-life balance

4. Preventive Medication Compliance:
   - Take propranolol daily as prescribed
   - Give prevention 2-3 months to show effect
   - Goal: Reduce migraine frequency by 50% or more
   - Monitor for side effects
   - Do not stop abruptly

5. Hormonal Management:
   - Track migraines in relation to menstrual cycle
   - Consider discussing hormonal contraception options with gynecologist
   - Some women benefit from extended-cycle birth control
   - May need additional treatment during menstrual phase

Follow-up Plan:

1. Return visit in 4-6 weeks:
   - Review headache diary
   - Assess response to preventive medication
   - Adjust treatment as needed
   - Monitor for medication overuse

2. Bring to follow-up appointment:
   - Completed headache diary
   - List of triggers identified
   - Record of all medications taken
   - Blood pressure log (check weekly)

3. Consider specialist referral if:
   - Inadequate response to preventive therapy
   - Chronic migraine develops (>15 headache days/month)
   - Medication overuse headache suspected
   - Complicated migraines or status migrainosus
   - Need for botox or other advanced therapies

Red Flags - Seek Emergency Care Immediately:
- Sudden severe headache ("thunderclap" - worst headache of life)
- Headache with fever and stiff neck
- Headache after head trauma
- New neurological symptoms (weakness, numbness, vision loss, speech problems)
- Change in pattern of headaches
- Headache with confusion or altered consciousness
- Persistent aura >60 minutes
- Headache with seizure

Work Accommodations:
- May need to leave work during acute migraine
- Request accommodations: adjustable lighting, regular breaks, quiet workspace
- Discuss with employer about flexibility during migraine episodes
- Consider disability paperwork if migraines severely impact work

Pregnancy Planning:
- Discuss with provider before conceiving
- Many migraine medications contraindicated in pregnancy
- Alternative treatment plan needed
- Some women experience improvement during pregnancy

Prognosis:
With appropriate preventive therapy, lifestyle modifications, and acute treatment, expect:
- 50-75% reduction in migraine frequency
- Decreased severity of episodes
- Improved quality of life
- Better ability to function during and between episodes
- Many patients achieve excellent control with comprehensive management

Resources:
- American Migraine Foundation: www.americanmigrainefoundation.org
- Migraine tracking apps (Migraine Buddy, N1-Headache)
- Support groups (online and local)
- Patient education materials provided
